captions.text:
Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday; I am hoooome!
Home is a nice place to be. I missed you,

slightly off-white bookshelf. And you, Dutch
nerdfighter shoes. And I even missed you,
probably mouse poop.

So Hank I really liked your video about the
Renaissance and circumstance and as I've been

re-reading Behind the Beautiful Forevers for
the nerdfighter book club--by the way, nerdfighters,

don't forget to read this book by June 10th!--anyway,
I've been thinking a lot about luck and deserving

what happens to you, probably in part because
I feel especially undeserving (with good reason)

of all the nice things that are happening
to me right now.

Like Hank, people keep congratulating me after
they see The Fault in Our Stars movie as if

I did anything, but all I did was get lucky.
Lucky that the book was published so well,

lucky to have a great cover, lucky that the
people I sold the movie rights to happened

to be brilliant, lucky that the wonderful
cast and crew and director came together to
make a great movie.

I mean Hank I didn't make savvy decisions
in this process or anything; I just got lucky.

There are much, much better books that have
been made into terrible, terrible movies.

But Hank of course the luck goes further back
than that because I'm lucky to have you as

a brother and collaborator. I'm lucky that
in 2007 you wrote a great song about Harry
Potter that gave us a whole new audience.

I happened to be born into a rich country
and I happened to be born male and white in

a culture that privileges male-ness and white-ness.
And I write in English, Hank, which is a massive

advantage, I mean YA writers writing in Latvian,
even those far more talented than I am, rarely
find broad audiences.

Like Hank, all this Fault in Our Stars movie
stuff is not happening because I am a good

person; that's not the way the world works.
And I hope I can remember that because when

you start to think that the good things that
have happened to you have happened because

you worked harder than other people, or because
the universe prefers you, you start to see

the world with this weird, self-centered myopia,
and you don't commit yourself to lessening

inequality or to supporting marginalized voices
because you don't think there's a problem.

You start to think that the world is as it
should be.

Now obviously, this is very bad for other
people, but I think ultimately it's also bad

for you. I don't mean you in particular, Hank,
you're a very nice person, I mean like the

hypothetical you. Because there will come
a day when awful and unjust things happen

to you, and if you believe that you deserved
the good things because you were oh-so-good,
does that mean you now deserve the bad things?

I would argue that in addition to not deserving
all of the wonderful things that happen in

life, we don't deserve all of the terrible
things. Like Hank, you don't deserve to have

ulcerative colitis; that's not fair. No one
deserves chronic pain or dementia or poverty.

It's almost like "deserving" isn't the best
way to imagine it.

So Hank I keep meaning to mention this, but
over at Crash Course, we're about to teach

a ten-episode series in Big History. This
is possible because of a grant from one of

Bill Gates' organizations. Basically we get
to chart the history of the universe, from

the Big Bang to, like, now. And I bring this
up because in Big History, we learn that 99.9%

of matter in the Solar System was sucked up
by the Sun as it formed. Everything else:

Jupiter, the Atlantic Ocean, my astonishingly
diverse collection of Polo shirts, the probable
mouse poop, all of that is the .1%.

In that context, everything in the solar system
not burning inside the Sun is on the very

far edge of the "good fortune" bell curve.
To me at least, Hank, it's not about deserving

anything, because you are not your luck. No
matter your circumstances, you are valuable
and rare and worthy of love.

And the great thing about humans, my favorite
thing about humans, actually, is that we can

work together to improve each other's chances
of having healthy and productive lives. And

whether it's cancer research or the Project
for Awesome or being kind to a stranger at

Walmart, for me, that is the only real path
to gratitude.

And I know that I'm saying this from an extremely
privileged position, but I really believe

that gratitude IS the proper response for
the absolute astonishment of getting to be

alive, and aware, and an essential part of
this crazy, sprawling story.

In short, Hank, I am very grateful to you
and to all of nerdfighteria. Hey, I wanna

tell you about two books I really like. I
know that you're busy reading Behind the Beautiful

Forevers, but! Everything Leads to You by
Nina LaCour and The Great Greene Heist by
Varian Johnson, both excellent!

Now I'm gonna try to go track down that mouse.
Hank, I'll see you on Friday.

comments.text:
I came back to watch this video because I believe so much in what you said, 
John. A very wise person shared this Leonard Cohen quote with me: "None of 
us deserving of the cruelty or the grace." It is so true that we do 
ourselves wrong by assuming we deserve anything we happen to get - 
blessings or burdens. I think it is so important to take deserving out of 
our understanding of life entirely. So thank you John for this video, it is 
a very important message needing to be received.﻿

comments.text:
Thank you for this post John. I would love it if you could use your book 
rec skills and privilege in doing more shout outs for authors and books 
with marginalised people as characters and/or authors (lgbt, poc, disabled, 
poor, outside of US/UK etc) I've been an avid reader all my life and even 
as a QTIPOC the amount of novels I've read with black authors or about 
black people I can probably count on one hand, which is becoming more and 
more unacceptable each day. I respect your book recs so anything you can 
offer on this would be amazing!﻿

comments.author: Roderick Daniels

comments.text:
The impostor syndrome (also spelled imposter syndrome), sometimes called 
impostor phenomenon or fraud syndrome, is a psychological phenomenon in 
which people are unable to internalize their accomplishments. Despite 
external evidence of their competence, those with the syndrome remain 
convinced that they are frauds and do not deserve the success they have 
achieved. Proof of success is dismissed as luck, timing, or as a result of 
deceiving others into thinking they are more intelligent and competent than 
they believe themselves to be.
My advice to John is to seek immediate psychiatric help before he hurts 
himself due to the depression he will soon feel for achieving more than 
couch potatoes.﻿
comments.author: Thomas Graham

comments.text:
"To me, at least, Hank, it's not about deserving anything because you are 
not your luck. No matter your circumstances, you are valuable and rare and 
worthy of love."

The point was not that he is unworthy of success, but rather that in 
general people should avoid feeling that they are successful because they 
deserve it more then others. I think the connotations of the word deserve 
and perhaps even the definition is not consistent between the way you are 
using it compared to John.
comments.author: BoredDan

comments.text:
+laura s He says he feels he doesn't deserve success because of the 
privileges bestown upon him at birth.  He completely disregards what he has 
done with his advantaged situation and the huge move from where he began. 
 It's a dangerous path to suicide, it's a cry for help, ignored he might do 
dangerous things.
Unless you're saying that he is simply lying about how he truly feels and 
that he is just saying these things to gain the sympathies of teenage girls 
who buy his books and watch his movies.  If you are saying that, I would 
have to give it some thought because it kind of does, in a somewhat 
demented way, fit the facts.  Perhaps it is just a ploy for future ticket 
and book sales.  If he doesn't actually feel that way, why would he say he 
feels that way?
You make a good point.  Perhaps he's just trying to manipulate the little 
girls to give him more money and idolize him for his false humility.
I thought he was being honest, but you make a good point.
comments.author: Thomas Graham

comments.text:
The point of the video was that nobody deserves to be successful or to 
fail. Not that he specifically doesn't deserve to be successful. He was 
just making the point that nobody deserves success or failure as such, and 
that becoming famous is down to luck. Which I think it is. There's no 
denying that he wrote a good book, but Looking For Alaska for example was, 
in my opinion, much better, and yet because he got lucky with a film 
company for the fault in our stars, he suddenly became really famous, which 
didn't happen with lfa just because he wasn't as lucky with the company 
that bought the rights. So I do understand what he's saying and I don't 
think he means that he isn't talented, or proud of his work. I think he's 
just saying that everyone kind of deserves success.
comments.author: laura s

comments.text:
+laura s That was the whole point of the video.  After making literally 
1200 videos in only 5 years, writing a book and consulting for a movie, he 
doesn't feel he "deserves" his success.  That is a problem that can lead to 
depression and suicide.  Feeling you deserve the credit and success of your 
work is an essential part of being a healthy human being.  Without it, over 
time it digresses to the inability to feel appreciated or loved, then 
conversely you loose the ability to feel compassion or empathy, until it 
leads to suicide.  Seriously, he needs help.
comments.author: Thomas Graham

comments.text:
This is a pointless argument :/ but whatever. It's nice that you really 
care, I guess. I just don't think he actually said he felt like that.
comments.author: laura s

comments.text:
+laura s I am not telling him how he feels, I'm just saying that if he 
feels the way he says he feels, he should seek help.
comments.author: Thomas Graham

comments.text:

as I said, he is not dismissing his talent, only telling us that he did not 
make the film. Which he didn't.
comments.author: laura s

comments.text:
+laura s unfortunately, making excuses for how you honestly feel is also 
part of the psychosis. John seems like a nice guy but if he truly feels 
this way he should not dismiss this very real, very serious mental problem 
and should seek help.
comments.author: Thomas Graham

comments.text:
I don't think he's denying that he is successful, or that he wrote a good 
book. I think he's just reminding people not to get too big-headed, that's 
all.
comments.author: laura s

comments.text:
Great video! I think some people look at privilege on an individual level. 
They look around and say "hey my life isn't perfect I'm not privileged". 
But I will say this I'm an ethnic minority in America (I say it in that way 
to take the focus off myself but give a general understanding of my view).

Also, I love Jon Green books and I'm happy for his success. So I'm not 
saying this from a place of hate at all, he does a lot of great things and 
works hard. But when you look at all of the MEGA successful books, and 
authors with huge followings most likely they are white, the characters are 
majority white, etc. This doesn't mean all white people are racist, or even 
most (I would hope) but it's one example of privilege. Authors of other 
races that write about their culture usually do not have the same exposure.

MOST white people (based on numbers here) are not going to buy a book with 
say a Black person on the cover, or a Black protagonist at the same rate as 
books with white characters. It's subconscious for the most part, but 
things like this are the reason why authors (or any person trying to appeal 
to the "masses" aka mainstream, aka white people at large) may whitewash 
their characters, change their book covers etc.

Twilight series, all of Jon Green's books, Harry Potter, 50 Shades of Grey, 
etc etc etc....yes MOST books, no matter who it was written by won't have 
this level of success. But if you are not writing from a perspective that 
is comfortable for "mainstream" you're almost dead in the water before you 
start. You CAN have success and can see books, but it most likely be at the 
same level as a successful white author.

This isn't an indictment of white people. Other races need to embrace 
authors that are out there too, white privileged runs deep.

And finally, I'm an ethnic/racial minority but I am also an AMERICAN, and 
middle-class. I have privilege too. Most of us do, even if you're reading 
this on the computer. But Jon is right, a WHITE AMERICAN, MALE, CHRISTIAN, 
STRAIGHT, and MIDDLE CLASS + as it stands has the MOST priviliedge in this 
country regardless of people's opinions, and it's good that he spoke out 
about how he is grateful and at least recognizes his position.﻿

comments.author: Joseph Johnston

comments.text:
Whether or not you deserve fame has absolutely nothing to do with your 
feelings.
You were born in the US, just like 400 million others, and yet you took 
same starting point, made over 1200 videos and several books.  
Deserve:  to do something or have or show qualities worthy of (reward or 
punishment).
Your actions fit the definition and therefore you deserve your fame, 
whether or not you feel you do.

The fact that you are indeed an intelligent individual makes me skeptical 
of your true feelings.  It's interesting that your interpersonal video 
comes out so close to your up coming movie premiere.  I'm not saying that 
you're playing the emotions of the 2 million little girls that follow you 
and buy your books......well, yeah, I guess I am saying that.﻿
comments.author: Thomas Graham

comments.text:
I got his point, and I get yours too (and agree with a bit of both)...I 
also see it from another perspective (and I think he does too, which is why 
he made the vid - or I assume). I wrote a longer comment, so will try to 
keep this short. But let's take an ethnic minority writing about ethnic 
characters versus a white person, writing about white people.

Because of sheer marketability (their are more white people in the U.S., 
maybe even better educated, more willing to buy books for leisure, etc.) a 
publisher may pick a book by a white person to represent over the minority 
(of the same quality) because they are trying to sell more books. Simple.

YouTube- Whites and Asians actually make up the majority of YT watchers, 
therefore MOST uber popular channels are either by Whites or Asians. Again 
just from sheer numbers and people watching others that "look" like them, 
similar interests etc.

I could go on, but basically what I'm saying is I think he realizes that 
despite hard work, there is still some "luck" even at the beginning because 
you're level of popularity or "repeatability" may be higher, exposure, etc. 
Don't get me wrong, I take nothing away from his success and own some of 
his books but yes these things do count...and they do matter.

And I'm glad that there is a push and (seemingly) a desire for more diverse 
books because maybe some "others" will be able to one day garner the same 
type of enthusiasm from readers and grow their audience. Because people 
with support seem to grow and people w/o may start off strong but 
eventually languish or at least settle for less.
comments.author: MissBeLight

comments.author: Cj Casey

comments.text:
I disagree with what you've said from 1:20 to 1:33 because evidently, those 
who do work harder than others can indeed lessen inequality and make the 
world in a better place and are certainly not so delusional as to become 
narcissistic and see themselves as better than others just because they 
think they are. Sure, that might be the case for a few, but from what I've 
learned in my life it's that oftentimes it's the few vocal people in a 
group that ruin it for the quiet, perfectly respectable majority. To note, 
of course, you shouldn't just see all of the good happening to you as you 
'deserving' and you shouldn't expect good to happen because you think you 
deserve it, which i think is what you were trying to get at with this 
video. But saying that just because some people work harder than others 
they will become delusional, myopic and oblivious to the bad and suffering 
of the world is absolute Warner Chilcott.﻿

comments.author: q

comments.text:
Actually, if you think about it, you generally do deserve the positive 
things more than the negative things. By default, humans are subject to 
live in the wilderness in abject poverty and misery, because nature/the 
universe/whatever does not care about whether we are happy or have 
"positive" things happen. However, if we build shelter, cultivate land... 
extend this to whatever you like, the results and success come due to 
deliberate human action. In other words, generally speaking, positive 
things mostly only happen because humans act deliberately, while negative 
things mostly happen by chance. This isn't to deny the reality of 
disproportion in the world, it's just pointing out a concept.﻿

The one, sole problem I have with this video is, if you are a deeply 
unlucky person who has suffered or been deprived of opportunities, is 
gratitude still the proper response? It's very grandiose to discuss 
ourselves in terms of all matter in the solar system or whatnot, but is the 
human response to pain really supposed to be stoicism or servility?﻿

Be grateful for the good things that happen, but not for the bad -- you 
don't have to be like "Thanks, person who just stole my life's savings!" 
but you can still appreciate the fact that while they were stealing your 
money, they were not murdering you, and you can appreciate this even while 
having the police track them down and imprison them.

comments.text:
Hey I do agree with that to a certain extent (as I believe in energy) but 
what do you think about babies that are born into the world in poverty, 
deformed, diseased. Or natural disasters that destroy the lives of 
hundreds, thousands+  etc etc etc.

I mean that's why I do agree with what he's saying to an extent because 
"deserve" is such a dangerous word. If you deserve the good, then you also 
deserve the bad, right? Which is similar to what you are saying here. I 
think in the end, I guess none of us really knows lol but it's interesting. 
And being positive makes me feel better, so I do try to stick with that ;)

comments.author: Curas1

comments.text:
What is absolutely crazy is that I can pick out some of the things you say 
in this video and match a few to your writing..... because I've read all of 
your books that are currently on shelf. You're truly a life changing 
writer. Thank you Mr. Green! ﻿
comments.author: Katie Poncet

comments.text:
Though I agree with you that a large portion of our life is circumstance 
and luck. I still value hard work in general in as an important factor. 
Whenever I achieve something, It's like in the back of my head I think, I 
think that there are 7 billion people in this world, and I am a small 
person in this large world, and very fortunate and grateful to have the 
opportunity to work hard to achieve this. The chance to even put that 
effort in, unfortunately is something that not everyone has and is 
something that is largely influenced by circumstance. But I still believe 
that with these opportunities we are given, our hard work can play an 
important part in how we shape the part of our lives that we can control. 
We should always be grateful for the opportunities to work hard, and 
therefore always but our best effort in.  ﻿
comments.author: PearlBlue5

comments.text:
"you are not your luck. no matter your circumstances, you are valuable and 
rare and worthy of love. and the great thing about humans, my favorite 
thing about humans actually, is that we can work together to improve each 
other's chances to have healthy and productive lives." you're brilliant, 
John.﻿
comments.author: Dana Facchine

comments.text: Heck yeah John Green. ﻿
comments.author: Nut Meg

comments.text:
This made me feel a little better about some situations in my life that 
I've been telling myself I deserve because I'm a crappy person. Not a 
crappy person in the sense that I treat people badly but in the sense that 
there's nothing noteworthy about me. Anyway, I won't go into detail. Just 
wanted to say thanks for the video. :)﻿
comments.author: Elizabeth W

comments.text:
Your discussion of luck and if we deserve the good or bad things that 
happen to us reminds me of a book, The Good Luck of Right Now by Matthew 
Quick. It just came out a few months ago and is without a doubt one of the 
best books I've read in a while!﻿
